text: Arnold Pick (20 July 18514 April 1924) was a Jewish Czech psychiatrist. He is known for identifying the clinical syndrome of Pick's disease and the Pick bodies that are characteristic of the disorder. He was the first to name reduplicative paramnesia. He was the second to use the term dementia praecox (in 1891). Ueber primäre chronische Demenz (so. Dementia praecox) im jugendlichen Alter. Prager medicinische Wochenschrift, 16, 312—15, 1891 Pick trained in Berlin with Carl Friedrich Otto Westphal and later worked at the infamous asylum of Wehnen. Pick headed the Prague neuropathological school and one of the school's members was Oskar Fischer. This school was one of the two neuropathological schools (the other one was in Munich where Alois Alzheimer worked) in Europe at the time that framed Alzheimer disease through empirical discoveries. == References == == External links == * * Biography of Arnold Pick at Who Named It Category:Czech psychiatrists Category:German psychiatrists Category:Jewish psychiatrists Category:Jewish neurologists Category:German Bohemian people Category:1851 births Category:1924 deaths Category:Deaths from sepsis Category:Czech Jews Category:People from Velké Meziříčí
